VOL. XXXI. No. 46

JUNE WEEK PROGRAM
IS ANNOUNCED
Festivities to Start on June 9 and
Last Six Days
ONE NEW FEATURE
Few Changes from Prospectus of
Former Years

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 12, 1927

PHI BETA KAPPA
TO HOLD BANQUET
Members of Phi Beta Kappa, honorary scholastic fraternity, who will be elected on
Wednesday, April 13, will be
initiated on the evening of
April 30. A banquet at the
Southern Hotel will follow
the ceremony. Albert Shaw,
editor of the Review of Reviews Magazine will be the
principal speaker of the occasion and Dr. H. Carrington
Lancaster, president of the
society will preside. Among
the notable guests present will
be Miss Lizette Woodsworth
Reese, Dean Emeritus Edward Herrick Griffin, Dr.
Welsh, and Dr. Hulbert. Men
are elected to Phi Beta Kappa
each year from the undergraduate, graduate, and medical
schools of the University.

WHITE AND DALSEMER
HEAD 1928 BLUEJAY

I

HOPKINS GOALIE

Elected Editor-in-Chief and Business
Manager Respectively

NEW POSITION CREATED
Banks, Kolb, Wood, Levi, and Medenbach on New Board

Donald W. White,'28, and Leonard Dalsemer, '28, were elected editor-in-chief and business manager,
respectively, of the Black and Blue
Jay at the annual banquet of the
organization held last night at the
Southern Hotel. White served as
managing editor during 1926-27,
and Dalsemer as advertising manager. The new chiefs succeed Larkin H. Farinholt, '27, and Maxwell
RAYMOND FINN
Cone, '27.
Playing His First Year As Hopkins
William B. Banks, '29, art editor
Net Guardian
for the past year, was elected managing editor, and Bennett Kolb, ISLANDS OF THE PACIFIC
'29, art editor. W. R. McDorman
PRESENT PROBLEM
'29, was elected to the editorial staff

THE JOHNS .HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 12, 1927

2

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

INTERCOLLEGIATE

FOUNDED 1897

NEWS
$2.00

Subscription

Entered as second-class matter December 3, 1909, at the Postoffice at
Baltimore, Md., under Act of Congress, November 3, 1879.
Published semi-weekly from October to June by the students of Johns
Hopkins University.
Business communications should be addressed to the BUSINESS MANAGER, JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY; all articles and other communications
should be sent to the MANAGING EDITOR.

Welcome news has once more
reached us that final examinations
at the University of Minnesota
have been practically abolished.
All seniors who have maintained
an average of C in their scholastic work will be exempt from final
examinations in four of the colleges of the University. This will
include by far a majority of the
senior class.

University 0100

ZANVYL KRIEGER, '28

The faculty of Heidelberg College has recently come out as being in favor of more sociability
among the students. Following
up this suggestion, they have set
aside seven days in each month
on which half of the men are to
dine at the girls' hall and half the
girls at the men's hall.

REMSEN HALL
About twice a year for the past two or three years people
have come forward with suggestions for changing the names
of the buildings on the campus. Why not, they say, rename
the Civil Engineering Building, the Mechanical Engineering
Building, and the Chemical Laboratory, honoring men who
have been conspicuous in their devotion and service to Hopkins.
No official notice has ever been given these suggestions,
though it would be an extremely simple matter to carry them •
out. Possibly there is no one whose name at present suggests
itself as appropriate for either of the engineering buildings,
but the time surely is most propitious for rechristening the
Chemical Laboratory.
The recent death of Dr. Ira Remsen presents an opportunity for honoring a great Hopkins scientist. Dr. Remsen
was one whose name will live as long as Johns Hopkins University continues to exist. His aid in the discovery of saccharin, his untiring love of research, his devotion to his life work,
and his unselfish attitude towards his profession are qualities
which are synonymous with his name.
To us, it seems that no more fitting memorial could be
made to the great chemist than by renaming the present
Chemical Laboratory in his honor. By calling that building
Remsen Hall, his name may be forever kept before the student body in the same way as Dr. Gillman's memory is perpetuated.

LOCAL TALENT IS GOOD ENOUGH
We do not know whether the decision of the June Week
Committee to hire a local orchestra for its dances was influenced chiefly by sumptuary reasons or whether it believed
that Baltimore couples can actually dance better to Baltimore
music. Either way, it seems to us, they were right.
The cost of importing an orchestra for three or four days
is probably four to five times the cost of using Mr. "Bob"
lula's excellent music. When a jazz band plays over the
radio once or twice it assumes that it has acquired a national
reputation, and hence its presence at a dance is supposed to
enhance the "good time had by all" to such an extent that it
can raise its rates five hundred per cent. Can't the dancers
say for the next week,"Why we had so-and-so's music—came
all the way from New Rochelle!"
This psychological effect is responsible for more than
half the enthusiasm aroused over out-of-town orchestras. The
average young man or girl could hardly distinguish the renowned George Olsen's band from "Bob" Iula's if he were not
told which were which. But combinations like that of Olsen
and others have Reputations, and can command huge prices.
When the glamor of June Week has worn off and the revelers have returned to the routine of their daily life, they will
probably thank the committee for saving them five or ten
dollars.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LE ITER, APRIL 12, 1927

SERGEANT FRANK
WARNS GAMESTERS
Sergeant Frank, acting on
orders from the office, appeared suddenly in the Trophy
Room in the Barn last Friday
and announced that if the use
of profane language in the
Barn is not discontinued immediately, the use of the second floor will be denied to students.
This announcement is the
culmination of a series of complaints received at the office
regarding the situation at the
Barn.

HE man who wins a race can't afford to
get complacent over it. His next step is to
improve on his own running time.
The electrical communication industry in
America ranks first in the world, with exceptional facilities for research and constructive
work.
But the men in this industry are never satisfied to let it go at that. No process, no matter
how satisfactory, by whom devised or how well
bulwarked by age,is hereimmunefrom challenge.
This dynamic state of mind must appeal
mightily to men who are pioneers at heart.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 12, 1927

PHI BETA KAPPA
TO HOLD BANQUET
Members of Phi Beta Kappa, honorary scholastic fraternity, who will be elected on
Wednesday, April 13, will be
initiated on the evening of
April 30. A banquet at the
Southern Hotel will follow
the ceremony. Albert Shaw,
editor of the Review of Reviews Magazine will be the
principal speaker of the occasion and Dr. H. Carrington
Lancaster, president of the
society will preside. Among
the notable guests present will
be Miss Lizette Woodsworth
Reese, Dean Emeritus Edward Herrick Griffin, Dr.
Welsh, and Dr. Hulbert. Men
are elected to Phi Beta Kappa
each year from the undergraduate, graduate, and medical
schools of the University.

WHITE AND DALSEMER
HEAD 1928 BLUEJAY

I

HOPKINS GOALIE

Elected Editor-in-Chief and Business
Manager Respectively

NEW POSITION CREATED
Banks, Kolb, Wood, Levi, and Medenbach on New Board

Donald W. White,'28, and Leonard Dalsemer, '28, were elected editor-in-chief and business manager,
respectively, of the Black and Blue
Jay at the annual banquet of the
organization held last night at the
Southern Hotel. White served as
managing editor during 1926-27,
and Dalsemer as advertising manager. The new chiefs succeed Larkin H. Farinholt, '27, and Maxwell
RAYMOND FINN
Cone, '27.

for the past year, was elected managing editor, and Bennett Kolb, ISLANDS OF THE PACIFIC
'29, art editor. W. R. McDorman
PRESENT PROBLEM
'29, was elected to the editorial staff

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

Subscription

Entered as second-class matter December 3, 1909, at the Postoffice at
Baltimore, Md., under Act of Congress, November 3, 1879.
Published semi-weekly from October to June by the students of Johns
Hopkins University.
Business communications should be addressed to the BUSINESS MANAGER, JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY; all articles and other communications
should be sent to the MANAGING EDITOR.

Welcome news has once more
reached us that final examinations
at the University of Minnesota
have been practically abolished.
All seniors who have maintained
an average of C in their scholastic work will be exempt from final
examinations in four of the colleges of the University. This will
include by far a majority of the
senior class.

ZANVYL KRIEGER, '28

The faculty of Heidelberg College has recently come out as being in favor of more sociability
among the students. Following
up this suggestion, they have set
aside seven days in each month
on which half of the men are to
dine at the girls' hall and half the
girls at the men's hall.

REMSEN HALL
About twice a year for the past two or three years people
have come forward with suggestions for changing the names
of the buildings on the campus. Why not, they say, rename
the Civil Engineering Building, the Mechanical Engineering
Building, and the Chemical Laboratory, honoring men who
have been conspicuous in their devotion and service to Hopkins.
No official notice has ever been given these suggestions,
though it would be an extremely simple matter to carry them •
out. Possibly there is no one whose name at present suggests
itself as appropriate for either of the engineering buildings,
but the time surely is most propitious for rechristening the
Chemical Laboratory.
The recent death of Dr. Ira Remsen presents an opportunity for honoring a great Hopkins scientist. Dr. Remsen
was one whose name will live as long as Johns Hopkins University continues to exist. His aid in the discovery of saccharin, his untiring love of research, his devotion to his life work,
and his unselfish attitude towards his profession are qualities
which are synonymous with his name.
To us, it seems that no more fitting memorial could be
made to the great chemist than by renaming the present
Chemical Laboratory in his honor. By calling that building
Remsen Hall, his name may be forever kept before the student body in the same way as Dr. Gillman's memory is perpetuated.

LOCAL TALENT IS GOOD ENOUGH
We do not know whether the decision of the June Week
Committee to hire a local orchestra for its dances was influenced chiefly by sumptuary reasons or whether it believed
that Baltimore couples can actually dance better to Baltimore
music. Either way, it seems to us, they were right.
The cost of importing an orchestra for three or four days
is probably four to five times the cost of using Mr. "Bob"
lula's excellent music. When a jazz band plays over the
radio once or twice it assumes that it has acquired a national
reputation, and hence its presence at a dance is supposed to
enhance the "good time had by all" to such an extent that it
can raise its rates five hundred per cent. Can't the dancers
say for the next week,"Why we had so-and-so's music—came
all the way from New Rochelle!"
This psychological effect is responsible for more than
half the enthusiasm aroused over out-of-town orchestras. The
average young man or girl could hardly distinguish the renowned George Olsen's band from "Bob" Iula's if he were not
told which were which. But combinations like that of Olsen
and others have Reputations, and can command huge prices.
When the glamor of June Week has worn off and the revelers have returned to the routine of their daily life, they will
probably thank the committee for saving them five or ten
dollars.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LE ITER, APRIL 12, 1927

SERGEANT FRANK
WARNS GAMESTERS
Sergeant Frank, acting on
orders from the office, appeared suddenly in the Trophy
Room in the Barn last Friday
and announced that if the use
of profane language in the
Barn is not discontinued immediately, the use of the second floor will be denied to students.
This announcement is the
culmination of a series of complaints received at the office
regarding the situation at the
Barn.

HE man who wins a race can't afford to
get complacent over it. His next step is to
improve on his own running time.
The electrical communication industry in
America ranks first in the world, with exceptional facilities for research and constructive
work.
But the men in this industry are never satisfied to let it go at that. No process, no matter
how satisfactory, by whom devised or how well
bulwarked by age,is hereimmunefrom challenge.
This dynamic state of mind must appeal
mightily to men who are pioneers at heart.
